summary: This document is a collection of forwarded emails from Sarah Ransome to various recipients, including political figures, journalists, and attorneys, primarily dated in March and April 2025. The emails contain allegations of evidence tampering, witness intimidation, and cover-ups related to the Jeffrey Epstein case, and demand investigations into numerous individuals and entities. The sender accuses attorneys, media figures, and government officials of profiting from and obstructing justice in the Epstein sex trafficking ring.

persons.name: Sarah Ransome
persons.context: The primary author of the emails, making extensive allegations of evidence tampering, witness intimidation, and cover-ups by attorneys, journalists, and government officials related to the Epstein case. She demands investigations and justice.

persons.name: Keir Starmer
persons.role: British Prime Minister (as of email date)
persons.context: Addressed in emails accusing the British government of cruelty, obstructing justice, and protecting perpetrators in the Epstein case. He is challenged to investigate Prince Andrew and reveal the truth.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: Repeatedly addressed as "President Trump" or "Mr. President" in emails pleading for assistance, investigations into various figures (Rishi Sunak, attorneys, journalists), protection for her family, and action against media outlets.

persons.name: David Boies
persons.context: Accused repeatedly of conflict of interest, perverting the course of justice, silencing victims, profiting from settlements, and having inappropriate relationships with clients and other figures like the Clintons. Former attorney for the sender.

persons.name: Brad Edwards
persons.context: Named as an attorney who represented Epstein victims, including the sender. Accused of being a "main Epstein employee," deleting evidence, profiting, and facilitating the sex trafficking ring.

persons.name: Sigrid McCawley
persons.context: Named alongside David Boies and Brad Edwards. Accused of participating in evidence tampering, psychological abuse, and profiting from victim settlements. Former attorney for the sender.

persons.name: Kash Patel
persons.context: Addressed directly in many emails. The sender urges him to investigate numerous individuals (attorneys, journalists, politicians), take witness statements, retrieve deleted evidence from her devices, and hold the media accountable.

persons.name: Alina Habba
persons.context: Asked to receive agreements and evidence, and to help with investigations. The sender states she has been included in correspondence and has evidence of what's been happening.

persons.name: Rishi Sunak
persons.context: Accused of having emails deleted from the sender's server and called for investigation into his financials. Mentioned as a former local MP who was contacted.

persons.name: Prince Andrew
persons.context: Referenced as someone Keir Starmer called to be investigated. Also mentioned in the context of Virginia Giuffre's allegations and the sender's demand for a full investigation into his and his family's involvement.

persons.name: Virginia Giuffre
persons.context: Mentioned in the context of a paid interview with 60 Minutes Australia about Prince Andrew. The sender questions her actions and motives.

persons.name: Julie Brown
persons.context: Accused of personal involvement, having victims sign HBO contracts to silence them, and charging for interviews about Epstein. The sender demands she be investigated.

persons.name: Daniel Bates
persons.context: Accused of bullying, intimidating the sender, and having worked with the sender's attorneys. Urged to contact the FCA with information about Peter Mandelson and others.

persons.name: Adam Castellani
persons.context: Repeatedly demanded to be found and held accountable. Described as a colleague of Jes Staley at JP Morgan who moved to Citi Bank. Photos of him in the sender's house are referenced.

persons.name: Jes Staley
persons.context: Central figure in an FCA investigation regarding false statements about his relationship with Epstein. The sender claims to have evidence and connects him to Adam Castellani.

persons.name: Peter Mandelson
persons.context: Accused of meeting with Jeffrey Epstein. The sender claims to have sold pictures of Mandelson with Epstein to the Daily Mail and demands he be investigated.

persons.name: Rupert Murdoch
persons.context: Accused of perverting the course of justice and profiting from the Epstein story. The sender demands he and his son Lachlan be investigated.

persons.name: Gayle King
persons.context: Accused of having inside information on Melinda Gates and others and withholding crucial evidence. Named as a witness.

persons.name: Steve Ross
persons.context: Asked to send a Viacom agreement he tried to force the sender to sign.

persons.name: Cyril Ramaphosa
persons.context: Accused of racism and involvement in trafficking girls out of South Africa. The sender demands his finances be investigated and that he be taken to court.

persons.name: Emmanuel Macron
persons.context: Accused of allowing Epstein to operate in France and not arresting him. The sender demands France be held accountable and pay compensation.

persons.name: Sergey Brin
persons.context: Accused of being on Epstein's island and having specific interests. The sender tells him he gets to "rape Sigrid's girls" in a sarcastic and threatening manner.

persons.name: Jamie Dimon
persons.context: Called a "monster" and accused of his bank deleting emails and funding Epstein's trafficking for decades. The sender demands he be investigated.

persons.name: Alan Dershowitz
persons.context: Mentioned as a named defendant who provided legal services to Prince Andrew and the Royal Family, which the sender claims breaks international law.

persons.name: Carolyn
persons.context: Referenced as a victim who was murdered (not suicide). The sender questions what happened to her compensation and children.

connections.description: Sarah Ransome was represented by David Boies in her Epstein litigation. She now accuses him of conflict of interest, psychological abuse, silencing her, and profiting from her case.
Brad Edwards was one of Sarah Ransome's attorneys. She accuses him of being a main Epstein employee, deleting evidence, and facilitating the trafficking ring.
Sigrid McCawley was one of Sarah Ransome's attorneys. She is accused alongside Boies and Edwards of evidence tampering and abuse.
Portrayed as working together as attorneys representing Epstein victims, including Sarah Ransome. Accused of coordinating to silence victims and profit.
Described as colleagues at JP Morgan at the same time, connecting the financial sector to the sender's allegations.
Sarah Ransome alleges Adam Castellani harmed her and was involved in the Epstein network. She demands he be found and held accountable.
Sarah Ransome repeatedly emails Kash Patel, the FBI Director, urging him to investigate numerous people, take her evidence, and hold the media accountable.
Sarah Ransome pleads with President Trump for help, investigations, protection for her family, and action against other governments and the media.
The sender claims Peter Mandelson met with Jeffrey Epstein and that she sold pictures of them together to the Daily Mail.
The sender claims David Boies was "exceptionally good friends" with Bill and Hillary Clinton, creating a conflict of interest in representing Epstein victims.
Implied connection through media coverage and legal dealings. The sender accuses them both of perverting justice.

events.title: Alleged Bus Accident Involving Virginia Giuffre's PR Person
events.description: Emails reference a PR person (Dini) for Virginia Giuffre being hit by a bus and having three days to live. The sender questions the authenticity of the story, the lack of injuries, and the jewelry worn in a hospital photo.

events.title: Sarah Ransome's Suicide Attempt
events.description: The sender references a suicide attempt on October 6, 2018, for which she holds her former attorneys David Boies and Sigrid McCawley responsible. She claims photos of the event have been deleted from her devices.

events.title: US Tennis Outing with Attorneys and Journalist
events.description: The sender recounts being taken to the US Open by her attorneys (David Boies, Sigrid McCawley, Brad Edwards) and journalist Kate Briquelet, using it as evidence of their close relationship.

events.title: Timeframe of Alleged Trafficking and Associations
events.description: Multiple references to events in 2006/2007: Sarah Ransome cooking for a friend in Epstein's apartment, Jean Luc Brunel giving her a disk, Sergey Brin and Anne Wojcicki being on Epstein's island, and Peter Mandelson meeting Epstein.

events.title: Media Reports on Virginia Giuffre's PR Person in Accident
events.description: News articles circulate about Virginia Giuffre's PR person being hit by a bus, which the sender mocks and questions in her emails.

events.title: FCA Correspondence Regarding Jes Staley
events.description: The FCA emails Sarah Ransome about their case against Jes Staley, concerning false statements about his relationship with Epstein. They ask for relevant evidence.

keyFacts: The sender, Sarah Ransome, a self-identified Epstein victim, alleges a widespread conspiracy involving attorneys (David Boies, Brad Edwards, Sigrid McCawley), journalists, and government officials to silence victims, tamper with evidence, and profit from the Epstein case.
She repeatedly claims that evidence, including emails and photos, has been deleted from her Apple devices and email accounts, and accuses her former attorneys of being responsible.

She demands investigations into numerous high-profile individuals, including Keir Starmer, Rishi Sunak, Emmanuel Macron, Cyril Ramaphosa, Rupert Murdoch, Jamie Dimon, and Peter Mandelson, for their alleged roles in obstructing justice or involvement in trafficking.

The emails reference a specific FCA investigation into Jes Staley regarding false statements about his relationship with Epstein, and connect him to Adam Castellani, a JP Morgan colleague the sender wants found.

The correspondence shows a pattern of the sender attempting to use political figures (Trump, Patel) and regulatory bodies (FCA, SEC) to bypass traditional legal channels she believes are corrupt or compromised.
